subSections.title: Alternative forms
subSections.text: * In [[Traditional Chinese]], Japanese [[kyūjitai]], Korean [[hanja]] and Vietnamese [[Hán Nôm]], the component [[File:U26c29-ue0102.svg|25px|text-bottom|𦰩󠄂|link=𦰩]] for this character is written with {{l|mul|廿}} on top. Note that the bottom portion is written {{l|mul|口}} overlapped by {{l|mul|夫}} and not {{l|mul|中}} on top of {{l|mul|天}}. * In Japanese [[shinjitai]], the component [[File:U26c29.svg|25px|text-bottom|𦰩|link=𦰩]] is written with {{l|mul|sc=Jpan|艹}} on top and has one stroke less. Due to [[w:Han unification|Han unification]], both traditional Chinese and Japanese shinjitai forms are encoded under the same [[code point]]. The appearance of this character will differ depending on the font used. * In [[Simplified Chinese]], the component [[File:U26c29-ue0102.svg|25px|text-bottom|𦰩󠄂|link=𦰩]] is simplified to {{l|mul|又}} instead, giving the character {{l|mul|叹}} (U+53F9). * Two [[w:CJK Compatibility Ideographs|compatibility ideographs]] exist for this character. U+FA37 corresponds to the [[kyūjitai]] form of this character while U+2F84C is an alternative form used in Taiwan and North Korea which is similar to Japanese shinjitai but the top right component is written {{lang|mul|sc=Hant|艹}} (4 strokes) instead of {{lang|mul|sc=Jpan|艹}} (3 strokes).
